row.entry: These rules require particulars to be included in pleadings and permit the court to order parties to give proper particulars. They stipulate the kinds of particulars required in relation to various specific kinds of claims.

These rules set out additional information and evidentiary documents required to be provided, in personal injury and compensation to relatives claims, after service of the statement of claim. They permit dismissal of the proceedings for non-compliance.

This rule complements s 82 of the CP Act, and requires plaintiffs to provide the detailed information and evidentiary documents required by rr 15.12 and 15.13, when any application is made for interim payments under that section.
This Division complements the defamation pleading rules in rr 14.30-14.40. It sets out the particulars required in connection with claims, and defences, in defamation proceedings.

Divisions 1–3 of this Part apply to all courts in Schedule 1 of the CP Act except rr 15.7, 15.8, and 15.12–15.17. Those provisions do not apply to the Local Court, Small Claims Division, and r 15.8 which does not apply in either the Dust Diseases Tribunal or the Local Court, Small Claims Division: see r 1.5 and Sch 1. Division 4 only applies to those courts exercising jurisdiction in relation to defamation proceedings and does not apply to the Local Court or the DDT.

Divisions 1–3 of this Part are based on the former SCR Part 16, DCR Part 9 and LCR Part 8. In relation to personal injury proceedings, it adopts the detailed requirements of the former Part 9 r 27 of the DCR. Division 4 is based on the former defamation rules in SCR Pt 67 and DCR Pt 49.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 15.1] r 15.1 Pleadings must give all necessary particulars (cf SCR Part 16, rules 1 and 1A; DCR Part 9, rule 19; LCR Part 8, rule 2)

leg:heading.title: Pleadings must give all necessary particulars (cf SCR Part 16, rules 1 and 1A; DCR Part 9, rule 19; LCR Part 8, rule 2)

p.text: Subject to this Part, a pleading must give such particulars of any claim, defence or other matter pleaded by the party as are necessary to enable the opposite party to identify the case that the pleading requires him or her to meet.
Subrule (1) does not require a pleading to give particulars of any claim for interest up to judgment other than those required by rule 6.12(7) .
Legislation cited in [15.1.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 14.7.

The scope of the criterion of “necessity” must depend both on judgment and on the circumstances of the individual case: Phillips v Phillips (1878) 4 QBD 127 at 139 ; Ratcliffe v Evans [1892] 2 QB 524 at 532 . Often the content of the particulars is a mere formality — in the sense that they demonstrably relate to matters of objective relevance to a proper understanding of the pleaded case: Philliponi v Leithead (1958) 59 SR (NSW) 352; 76 WN (NSW) 150; Grollo & Co Pty Ltd v Hammond (1977) 16 ALR 123 at 126 . On the other hand, sometimes the particulars sought may constitute a form of oppression by seeking details of the pleader ’s case that go far beyond any fair view of what can reasonably be necessary to allow the party requesting them to know the case it has to meet: Rosenstraus v Muscat [1965] NSWR 302 ; Dougherty v Nationwide News Pty Ltd (1967) 86 WN (Pt 1) (NSW) 181 . In each case, the determination of what particulars might be “necessary” for that purpose will be influenced by a desire to strike an appropriate balance between the entitlement of the opposing party to fair notice of the case to be met and the legitimate interest of the pleading party in retaining a proper degree of flexibility in the preparation and presentation of its case: see for example James v Smith [1891] 1 Ch 384 . Sometimes the judgment as to what is “necessary” may be complicated by the somewhat arbitrary nature of the distinction between material facts and particulars — as to which see the notes to r 14.7 .

Aside from these general observations, certain basic propositions can be advanced. Particulars will not be ordered of a pleading which merely puts the opponent to proof: Fox v H Wood (Harrow) Ltd [1963] 2 QB 601 at 605; [1962] 3 All ER 1100 . This is so even where the defence traverses a wholly negative allegation in the statement of claim: Weinberger v Inglis [1918] 1 Ch 133 . If, however, it is apparent that the defence, despite the negative form in which it is couched, will involve the defendant in attempting to make out an affirmative allegation — that is, it is a “pregnant negative” — particulars may be ordered (Pinson v Lloyds and National Provincial Foreign Bank Ltd [1941] 2 KB 72 at 79; [1941] 2 All ER 636 ; Chapple v Electrical Trades Union [1961] 3 All ER 612 at 615; [1961] 1 WLR 1290 at 1293 ; Howard v Borneman [1972] 2 All ER 867 at 871; [1972] 1 WLR 863 at 868 ; Dwyer v National Trustees Executors & Agency Co of Australasia Ltd [1939] VLR 96 at 101–2; [1939] ALR 164 ). Particulars may also be ordered if the real nature of the denial is in doubt: Johnstone v Sewell [1962] QWN 36 .

The purpose of particulars is to identify the scope of the facts properly relevant to the issues raised in the proceedings. They complement the material allegations in the pleadings but their purpose is not to supplement or expand those issues: Goldsmith v Sandilands (2002) 190 ALR 370; 76 ALJR 1024; [2002] HCA 31; BC200204358 at [2] . Particulars define the scope of the evidence to be lead at trial and are intended to prevent surprise by giving the opposing parties sufficient information to enable them to know the nature of that evidence: Pilato v Metropolitan Water Sewerage & Drainage Board (1959) 76 WN (NSW) 364 at 365 ; Spedding v Fitzpatrick (1888) 38 Ch D 410 at 413–14 ; National Starch Co v Robert Harper & Co Pty Ltd [1906] VLR 8 at 12; (1905) 11 ALR 335 ; Miller v Miller Autobody Co Ltd (1922) 39 WN (NSW) 201 at 203 ; Grollo & Co Pty Ltd v Hammond (1977) 16 ALR 123 at 126 ; Commercial Bank of Australia Ltd v Thomson [1964–5] NSWR 410; (1964) 81 WN (Pt 1) (NSW) 553 at 557, 558; 81 WN (Pt 1) (NSW) 553 ; Ellis v Grant (1970) 91 WN (NSW) 920 at 924, 925 ; see also Philipps v Philipps (1878) 4 QBD 127 at 139; [1874-80] All ER Rep Ext 1684 and Wise v Wise [1944] P 56 at 58. Particulars may also inform the scope of discovery that may be required: Saunders v Jones (1877) 7 Ch D 435 at 451 ; Mummery v Irvings Pty Ltd (1956) 96 CLR 99 at 110; [1956] ALR 795; BC5600580 ; Kelly v Kelly (1950) 50 SR (NSW) 261 at 265; 67 WN (NSW) 193 at 196 ; Bailey v FCT (1977) 136 CLR 214 at 219, 221, 227–8; 13 ALR 41; BC7700020 . By informing the scope of the material relevant to both pre-trial preparation and to the conduct of the trial itself, particulars are intended to reduce costs by assisting the parties to avoid incurring expense in preparing to meet issues that may never be put: McSpedden v Harnett (1942) 42 SR (NSW) 116 at 119; 59 WN (NSW) 98 ; Turner v Dalgety & Co Pty Ltd (1952) 69 WN (NSW) 228 at 229 ; Astrovlanis Compania Naviera SA v Linard [1972] 2 QB 611 at 620 ; Builders Licensing Board v Inglis (1985) 1 NSWLR 592 at 596 ; Banque Commerciale SA (in liq) v Akhil Holdings Ltd (1990) 169 CLR 279 at 286–7; 92 ALR 53 at 58–9; BC9002932 .

Despite the generality of various descriptions of the purpose of particulars, there are restrictions upon the detail that can properly be required by way of particulars. In broad terms, it has been said that particulars are permissible, and required, where they are necessary to inform the opposing party of the nature of the case it has to meet — as distinct from the mode in which that case is to be proved: Duke v Wisden (1897) 77 LT 67 at 68 ; GW Young & Co Ltd v Scottish Union and National Insurance Co (1907) 24 TLR 73 at 74 ; Spedding v Fitzpatrick (1888) 38 Ch D 410 at 413 ; R v Associated Northern Collieries (1910) 11 CLR 738 at 740–1; 17 ALR 359 ; Dare v Pulham (1982) 148 CLR 658 at 664; 44 ALR 117; BC8200139 ; Philliponi v Leithead (1958) 59 SR (NSW) 352; 76 WN (NSW) 150 at 151–2; Trade Practices Commission v Total Australia Ltd (1975) 24 FLR 413 at 415 ; Gould v Mount Oxide Mines Ltd (in liq) (1916) 22 CLR 490 at 517; [1916] HCA 81 . In elaborating this distinction some of the cases contain statements, at first sight rather surprising, to the effect that it is not the function of particulars to enlighten a party as to the true facts of the case (ie, all relevant details): Philliponi v Leithead, aboveat 153; Thorp v Holdsworth (1876) 3 Ch D 637 at 639 ; Bruce v Odhams Press Ltd [1936] 1 KB 697 at 712–13 ; Turner v Dalgety & Co Pty Ltd (1952) 69 WN (NSW) 228 at 229 ; Emmerton v University of Sydney [1970] 2 NSWR 633 at 635 ; Bailey v FCT (1977) 136 CLR 214 at 219, 220, 221; 13 ALR 41 . The reality is that the distinction is difficult to draw clearly because there is often a fine line between giving particulars of the case which a party proposes to make and disclosing the evidence by which that case is to be proved. Ultimately the distinction between what is a proper matter for particulars and what is not depends upon an assessment of what is reasonably necessary to protect the other party against surprise: see Sims v Wran [1984] 1 NSWLR 317 at 321 , which contains a useful summary of the principles and authorities. Particulars must be sought for the purposes set out in [15.1.10] above and not merely in the hope that they will provide a defendant to an action with facts upon which to found a defence (see per Ferguson J in Commercial Bank of Australia Ltd v Thomson [1964–5] NSWR 410 at 415; (1964) 81 WN (Pt 1) (NSW) 553 at 559 ), or provide a plaintiff to an action with material upon which it can seek to widen the scope of its claim or establish facts which may assist it in attacking the validity and legal effect of what the defendant has done: Grollo & Co Pty Ltd v Hammond (1977) 16 ALR 123 at 128 .

Generally, a party is bound by the facts particularised, in the sense that the particulars limit the evidence that can be given at the trial: Mummery v Irvings Pty Ltd (1956) 96 CLR 99 at 111; [1956] ALR 795 ; Bailey v FCT (1977) 136 CLR 214 at 219; 13 ALR 41 ; Esso Petroleum Co Ltd v Southport Corp [1956] AC 218 per Lord Radcliffe at 241; [1955] 3 All ER 864 (reliance on particulars is not mere pedantry). Depending upon the circumstances, however, a degree of flexibility is allowable in determining whether evidence is reasonably within the scope of the particulars which have been provided. For example, a court will not be overly restrictive in relation to particulars of an oral contract or representation — because it is almost inevitable that the evidence will not accord precisely with the language of the particulars: Dominion Factors Pty Ltd v LJ Hooker Ltd [1963] NSWR 573; SR (NSW) 146 ; see also George Patterson Pty Ltd v James Wallace Pty Ltd [1964–5] NSWR 1299. In any event, a trial judge has a discretion to allow amendment of particulars where it is necessary in order to determine the true issues of fact between the parties: Vlasic v Federal Capital Press of Australia Pty Ltd (1976) 9 ACTR 1 at 6 ; Douglas v John Fairfax & Sons Ltd [1983] 3 NSWLR 126 at 133 . Moreover, evidence which goes beyond the scope of the original particulars may, subject to any valid objection, emerge at the trial and, where this occurs, the disparity between the evidence and the earlier particulars will not disentitle a party from obtaining a verdict based upon the actual evidence before the court: Water Board v Moustakas (1988) 180 CLR 491 at 497; 77 ALR 193 ; Dare v Pulham (1982) 148 CLR 658 at 664; 44 ALR 117; BC8200139 ; Leotta v Public Transport Commission (NSW) (1976) 9 ALR 437 at 446; 50 ALJR 666 . In an appropriate case the particulars may be amended even after the evidence in the trial has closed: Mummery v Irvings Pty Ltd (1956) 96 CLR 99 at 110; [1956] ALR 795 . The test is whether the amendment of the pleadings or particulars will result in injustice to the other party by raising a point that could possibly have been met by relevant evidence during the course of the trial: Water Board v Moustakas, above, CLR at 497 ; Vlasic v Federal Capital Press of Australia Pty Ltd, above, at 6 .

A party’s obligation is only to supply the best particulars that they can. However, unless the party is in a representative capacity, they will need to establish that their objection (to providing further particulars) is genuinely based on an inability to provide further information. Even where such an objection is genuinely made, the requested party may still have to deliver the best particulars they presently can, and then supplement the particulars after discovery: Marshall v Inter Oceanic Steam Yachting Co (1885) 1 TLR 394 ; Leonard (Cyril) & Co v Simo Securities Trust Ltd [1971] 3 All ER 1313; [1972] 1 WLR 80 . As to representative parties, see Higgins v Weekes (1888) 5 TLR 238; Race Relations Board v Ealing London Borough Council (No 2) [1978] 1 All ER 497; [1978] 1 WLR 112 .

The form of particulars in actions in tort will vary with the allegation. For example, an allegation of trespass will not necessarily require particulars of the precise description of the particular parts of the land where the trespass occurred: New Zealand Land Assn v Mooney (1899) 16 WN (NSW) 89 ; see also Sutton v Ahern (1889) 15 VLR (L) 262. In conspiracy, the defendant is entitled to particulars of the manner in which the alleged conspiracy was brought about. If it is alleged that the effect of the conspiracy was that persons broke their contract with the plaintiff, then those persons should be named: Briton Medical & General Life Assn Ltd v Britannia Fire Assn (1888) 59 LT 888 ; Temperton v Russell [1893] 1 QB 435; [1893] 9 TLR 318 at 319 (on appeal); Temperton v Russell [1893] 1 QB 715 ; but cf Martell v Victorian Coal Miner’s Assn (1903) 29 VLR 475 at 510 in which this was doubted. In an action for passing off, if the statement of claim alleges sales on particular dates, then there should be particulars with regard to the circumstance in which each sale was made, and some identification of the person by whom each sale was made, but not a statement of the names and addresses of the purchasers: National Starch Co v Robert Harper & Co Pty Ltd [1906] VLR 8 at 12 ; Lemon & Co Pty Ltd v Moran & Cato Pty Ltd [1921] VLR 240 at 244 ; see also Claudius Ash Sons & Co Ltd v Invicta Manufacturing Co (1912) 29 RPC 465 . A defendant also may be ordered to give particulars. Thus, if in a false imprisonment action justification is pleaded, then particulars of that justification will be required to be provided: Stapeley v Annetts [1970] 1 WLR 20; [1969] 3 All ER 1541; Green v Garbutt (1912) 28 TLR 575; Gee Suey v Lehmert (1904) 10 ALR 248 .

In contract cases a party is usually entitled to particulars of the form of the contract, including the form of particular terms, the circumstances of its making and the consideration alleged: Cooke v Rickman [1911] 2 KB 1125 at 1130 . Apart from those matters, the nature of the particulars that will be ordered depends on the circumstances of each case. For instance, in a wrongful dismissal case, particulars may be ordered of what notice the plaintiff says would have been reasonable notice to determine the employment: Monk v Redwing Aircraft Co Ltd [1942] 1 KB 182; [1942] 1 All ER 133 . Where, in such proceedings, the defendant alleges misconduct, particulars of the acts and occasions of the misconduct must be given: Reid v Tooth & Co Ltd (1923) 23 SR (NSW) 487 at 490–4 .

In defamation, the extrinsic facts relied on to identify the plaintiff should be provided by way of particulars and not pleaded as material facts: Turner v Bulletin Newspaper Co Pty Ltd (1974) 131 CLR 69; 3 ALR 491 ; Dawson Bloodstock Agency Pty Ltd v Mirror Newspapers Ltd [1979] 2 NSWLR 733 .

Particulars are concerned with the nature of the case which is to be made by way of evidence and are not to be used, except in an extraordinary case, to ascertain the legal characterisation which a party places upon the facts and matters already identified in the particulars: Master Butchers Ltd v Cmr of Taxation [1974] 1 NSWLR 350 at 359 ; Sims v Wran [1984] 1 NSWLR 317 at 322 . However, if such argumentative matters or concepts are not made clear in the pleadings or apparent from the facts and matters particularised, the other party may in some cases be entitled to particulars in order to know the nature of the case it has to meet: Sims v Wran, above.

In a money claim, the appropriate particulars should be set out to show how the defendant’s receipt of the money was a receipt to the use of the plaintiff. Where the claim is for goods sold and delivered, the particulars should show either the invoice numbers and amounts or the nature of the goods and the dates of supply and the price of each item: Parpaite Frères v Dickinson (1878) 38 LT 178; Hall v Symons (1892) 92 LT Jo 337. In an action for a liquidated sum, the plaintiff should give particulars showing how the amount claimed is made up (George Patterson Pty Ltd v James Wallace Pty Ltd [1964–5] NSWR 1299), and should also give particulars of items for which credit is allowed to the defendant in the claim: Godden v Corsten (1879) 5 CPD 17 . Similar principles may apply to an action of account where what is really claimed is a definite sum: Kemp v Goldberg (1887) 36 Ch D 505 ; Maher v Maher [1961] Qd R 333 , but not where the action is a traditional action of account where the court has to ascertain what is due: Re Wells [1962] 2 All ER 826; [1962] 1 WLR 874. See also Lazar v Williamson (1884) 1 WN (NSW) 33.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 15.2] r 15.2 Use of ″Scott Schedule″ in building, technical and other cases (cf DCR Part 9, rule 19A; LCR Part 8, rule 7)

leg:heading.title: Use of "Scott Schedule" in building, technical and other cases (cf DCR Part 9, rule 19A; LCR Part 8, rule 7)

p.text: In proceedings involving a building, technical or other matter in which several items of a claim are in dispute as to liability or amount, or both, the party making the claim may, and if the court so orders must, prepare and file a “Scott Schedule” in the approved form.
A party on whom a Scott Schedule is served must complete and file the Schedule.
The approved form is Form 13 : Scott Schedule.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 15.3] r 15.3 Allegations of behaviour in the nature of fraud (cf SCR Part 16, rule 2; DCR Part 9, rule 20)

leg:heading.title: Allegations of behaviour in the nature of fraud (cf SCR Part 16, rule 2; DCR Part 9, rule 20)

p.text: A pleading must give particulars of any fraud, misrepresentation, breach of trust, wilful default or undue influence on which the party relies.

level.toc-caption: [15.3.5] Specific pleading and particulars — allegations in the nature of fraud

p.text: Legislation cited in [15.3.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.

heading.title: Specific pleading and particulars — allegations in the nature of fraud

p.text: UCPR r 15.3 mandates that a pleading must contain appropriate particulars of allegations involving specific types of fraudulent, wilful and improper conduct. UCPR r 15.4 also imposes a similar mandatory requirement that pleadings must include particulars of any alleged “condition of mind” — a wide term that not only includes physiological and psychological disorders or disabilities that significantly affects a person’s capacity to reason and understand but also includes states of mind, such as malice and intention. As the reference to fraud in both rules suggests, the two rules overlap to a degree. Both derive from changes to the English Supreme Court rules that reversed the effect of the decision in Burgess v Beethoven Electric Equipment Ltd [1943] KB 96 at 98; [1942] 2 All ER 658 (where the Court of Appeal held that the prior rules precluded an order for particulars of an allegation of illegal contractual intention). (A convenient summary of the history of the rules regarding particulars of condition of mind may be found in Lyons v Kern Konstructions (Townsville) Pty Ltd (1983) 47 ALR 114 at 124–5; 70 FLR 135 at 145–7; (1983) ATPR ¶40-343 .)

Fraud involves an explicit allegation of dishonesty. It is a serious allegation and requires proper pleading and particularisation: see r 14.14(3) and r 14.14.25 . The same applies to allegations of misrepresentation. The statement of claim must allege the nature and extent of each misrepresentation relied upon and the precise circumstances in which it was made, including identifying any document constituting the misrepresentation: Newport (Mon) Slipway Dry Dock & Engineering Co v Paynter (1886) 34 Ch D 88 ; Seligmann v Young [1884] WN 93. The allegation should not be expressed in general and ambiguous terms that are likely to be embarrassing to the opposing party: J Earle Hermann Ltd v Ferry (1915) 32 WN (NSW) 31 .

A defendant is entitled to particulars of the facts alleged to constitute him a trustee: Miller v Registrar General (1926) 43 WN (NSW) 135 . Full particulars must be given of any allegations of breach of trust or fraudulent breach of trust: Banque Commerciale SA (in liq) v Akhil Holdings Ltd (1990) 169 CLR 279; 92 ALR 53; BC9002932 ; Dwyer v National Trustees Executors & Agency Co of Australasia Ltd [1939] VLR 96 at 100–2; [1939] ALR 164 . This is particularly required in respect of an allegation of wilful or dishonest default: Belmont Finance Corp Ltd v Williams Furniture Ltd [1979] Ch 250; [1979] 1 All ER 118 . The particulars must include specific identification of the conduct alleged to constitute a breach of trust and the basis for the allegation of breach: Re Symons (1882) 21 Ch D 757 ; Smith v Armitage (1993) 24 Ch D 727 . Mere proof of breach of trust in one respect does not permit the court thereafter to direct a roving enquiry to ascertain whether there are other breaches of trust: Re Wrightson [1908] 1 Ch 789 at 799 ; see also Re Anstice (1885) 54 LJ Ch 1104.

Allegations of undue influence may arise either in relation to uncommercial transactions between “associated” persons: Bruty v Edmundson [1917] 2 Ch 285 at 292 (affirmed on appeal Bruty v Edmundson [1918] 1 Ch 112 ) (transaction between father and son); Frederick v South Australia (2006) 94 SASR 545; [2006] SASC 165; BC200604032 (magistrate’s resignation allegedly procured by undue influence of Chief Justice); or in relation to testamentary dispositions. If a defendant in probate proceedings alleges that the will was obtained by undue influence, or that the testator lacked relevant testatmentary capacity, the pleading must contain particulars of the character of, and the specific conduct alleged to constitute, the undue influence and particulars of the alleged testamentary incapacity: Queensland Trustees Ltd v Masterson [1987] 2 Qd R 704 at 707 ; Keane v Keane [1930] QWN 14 ; (but not merely evidentiary particulars – such as the names of the persons present at a particular time): Estate of the Earl of Shrewsbury; McLeod v Earl of Shrewsbury [1922] P 112 .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 15.4] r 15.4 Allegations as to condition of mind (cf SCR Part 16, rule 3; DCR Part 9, rule 21)

leg:heading.title: Allegations as to condition of mind (cf SCR Part 16, rule 3; DCR Part 9, rule 21)

p.text: A pleading that alleges any condition of mind must give particulars of the facts on which the party pleading relies.
In subrule (1), condition of mind includes any disorder or disability of mind, any malice and any fraudulent intention, but does not include knowledge.

level.toc-caption: [15.4.2] Specific pleading and particulars — allegations about “conditions of mind”

p.text: Legislation cited in [15.4.2] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 15.3, UCPR r 15.4.

heading.title: Specific pleading and particulars — allegations about “conditions of mind”

p.text: UCPR r 15.4 complements r 15.3 (see [15.3.5] ) and mandates that a pleading must contain particulars of any “condition of mind” — a term that includes any allegations of particular states of mind as well as allegations of relevant disorder or disability: see also [15.3.5] .

Good faith may become relevant in proceedings as a response to other allegations — for example an allegation of malice in proceedings for malicious prosecution. A mere denial, for example a denial that the prosecution lacked reasonable and probable cause, does not involve any affirmative allegation and does not create any obligation to provide particulars of the denial: Stapely v Annets [1970] 1 WLR 20; [1969] 3 All ER 1541; Weinberger v Inglis [1918] 1 Ch 133 at 140 . Good faith may also be relevant where the existence of a particular state of mind is a precondition to the claim. For example, where the Commissioner of Taxation’s opinion was a condition of the validity of a taxation assessment, in any proceedings to recover the tax assessed the Commissioner may be required to give particulars of the formation of the opinion. See Western Australian Capital Investment Co Ltd v FCT (1989) 87 ALR 183; 20 ATR 779; 89 ATC 4533 . Finally “good faith” may be relied on as affirmative defence. For example, trustees who, in answer to allegations of willful default, plead an affirmative case of having acted reasonably and in good faith, may be ordered to furnish particulars: Dwyer v National Trustees Executors & Agency Co of Australasia Ltd [1939] VLR 96 at 100–3; [1939] ALR 164 .

In some causes of action intention, belief and opinion may be relevant and may overlap with issues such as “good faith” and the objective existence of “reasonable and probable cause”. Particulars of intention may also be ordered: Feeney v Rix [1968] Ch 693; [1968] 3 All ER 22 (allegation that the party pleading never intended that certain payments to the other party should be a gift). And where an issue of intention is likely to be contentious, it would be prudent to include the particulars in the relevant pleading, even if that is not actually mandatory under the present rule.

Knowledge is specifically excluded from the description of “a condition of mind” in relation to which the present rule requires “particulars of the facts” on which the allegation is based. But this exclusion relates only to the mandatory requirement to include those particulars in the pleading. It does not preclude, and indeed UCPR r 15.10(2) specifically contemplates, orders being made requiring a party to provide particulars of the facts from which the inference of knowledge is to be drawn. The question whether particulars of knowledge should be ordered in any particular case depends on whether they are either “necessary” within the meaning of UCPR r 15.1 , or “convenient” within the meaning of UCPR r 2.1 . The answer to these questions will sometimes require a close examination of the pleadings under consideration in the particular proceedings: Travel Compensation Fund v Blair [2004] NSWSC 662; BC200404996 at [10] (particulars of knowledge of likelihood of insolvency); Idoport Pty Ltd v National Australia Bank Ltd [2000] NSWSC 599; BC200003738 , Einstein J at [52]–[54] (particulars of knowledge of statutory contravention under TPA s 75B .
Legislation cited in [15.4.20] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.

Malice may be relevant to some damages issues (see McMahon v Gardner [1968] Tas SR (NC) N32 and UCPR rr 5.7 and 15.8 ) to causes of action for malicious prosecution and to defences in defamation. A mere denial of malice does not require particulars: Stapeley v Annetts [1970] 1 WLR 20; [1969] 3 All ER 1541. But particulars may be ordered if the defendant pleads alleges reasonable and probable cause as a defence to a claim for malicious prosecution: Dwyer v National Trustees Executors & Agency Co of Australasia Ltd [1939] VLR 96; [1939] ALR 164 . In defamation proceedings where the defendant pleads defences of fair comment or privilege, the plaintiff will be required to give particulars of any reply alleging the defendant was actuated by malice. See UCPR r 13.10(3)(b) ; Duffield v Arts Council of South Australia Inc (1981) 27 SASR 540 . In such a case the particulars must deal with the motive for the making of the statement, not its truth or falsity: Mann v Board of Health (ACT) (1996) 67 FCR 383; BC9602595 , referring to Lord Diplock in Horrocks v Lowe [1975] AC 135 at 149; [1974] 1 All ER 662 at 669 . The particulars must do more than repeat allegations of absence of belief in the truth of the publication: NRMA Insurance Ltd v Flanagan [1982] 1 NSWLR 585 . The particulars must identify the matters relied upon to justify the inference of absence of belief.

Whenever it is material to allege notice to any person of any fact, matter or thing, it is sufficient to allege such notice as a fact unless the form or the precise terms of such notice or the circumstances from which such notice is to be inferred are material: NRNQ v MEQ Nickel Pty Ltd [1991] 2 Qd R 592 at 599 ; Cresta Holdings Ltd v Karlin [1959] 3 All ER 656; [1959] 1 WLR 1055 . Sometimes the allegation is that the opposing party “knew or ought to have known”. In relation to such an allegation particulars should be given of the facts and circumstances which it is claimed exist and from which it is said that the defendant ought to have acquired, either by observation or by inference, the relevant knowledge: Fox v H Wood (Harrow) Ltd [1963] 2 QB 601; [1962] 3 All ER 1100 ; Johnstone v HIH Insurance [2004] FCA 190; BC200400786 , Tamberlin J at [28].

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 15.5] r 15.5 Allegations of negligence and breach of statutory duty in common law claims in tort (cf SCR Part 16, rule 4; DCR Part 9, rule 22; LCR Part 8, rule 4)

leg:heading.title: Allegations of negligence and breach of statutory duty in common law claims in tort (cf SCR Part 16, rule 4; DCR Part 9, rule 22; LCR Part 8, rule 4)

p.text: The particulars to be given by a pleading that alleges negligence (whether contributory or otherwise):
must state the facts and circumstances on which the party pleading relies as constituting the alleged negligent act or omission, and

if the party pleading alleges more than one negligent act or omission, must, so far as practicable, state separately the facts and circumstances on which the party relies in respect of each alleged negligent act or omission.
The particulars to be given by a pleading that alleges breach of statutory duty:
must state the facts and circumstances on which the party pleading relies as constituting the alleged breach of statutory duty, and

if the party pleading alleges more than one breach of statutory duty, must, so far as practicable, state separately the facts and circumstances on which the party relies in respect of each alleged breach of statutory duty.

In actions in tort, the required particulars will vary according to the precise nature of the cause of action. The function of particulars in an action for negligence is to show what actions or omissions will be put forward as constituting the cause of action: Anchor Products Ltd v Hedges (1966) 115 CLR 493 at 499 . McCormack v Gilchrist, Watt & Sanderson Pty Ltd [1962] NSWR 462 at 464 . In a negligence action, the plaintiff “ought to state the facts upon which the supposed duty is founded, and the duty to the plaintiff with the breach of which the defendant is charged”: Gautret v Egerton (1867) LR 2 CP 371 per Willes J, cited in West Rand Central Gold Mining Co Ltd v R [1905] 2 KB 391 at 400 . It is not sufficient merely to plead negligence generally without specifying specifically the acts of negligence relied upon: Suvaal v Cessnock City Council (2003) 200 ALR 1; 38 MVR 289; [2003] HCA 41; BC200304309 . Neither is it sufficient to claim reliance upon facts that will appear in the evidence at the hearing of the action: Zanardo v Ford Motor Co of Australia Ltd [1964] VR 769 ; or upon “all the provisions of the Highway Code applicable”, see Wells v Weeks [1965] 1 All ER 77.

Particulars showing the respects in which it is contended the defendant was negligent must be given: Watson v North Metropolitan Tramways Co (1886) 3 TLR 273; Sneddon v Moro [1958] Qd R 494 ; Turner v Dalgety & Co Ltd (1952) 69 WN (NSW) 228 at 229 ; McCormick v Gilchrist, Watt & Sanderson Pty Ltd [1962] NSWR 462 . For example, if it is alleged the defendant drove whilst under the influence of alcohol, that should be specifically particularised: Roe v McGregor [1968] 2 All ER 636 at 641 . However, the particulars need not be set out as if each gave rise to a separate cause of action. It is sufficient if they are described as particulars of breach of the duty to take reasonable care: Karatzidis v Victorian Railways Cmrs [1971] VR 360 at 365 ; Vlahos v Easywear (Aust) Pty Ltd [1974] VR 155 at 159 . See also Katsilis v BHP Co Ltd (1977) 18 ALR 181 and cf Orlicki v Brisbane City Council [1961] Qd R 546 . Nor are the particulars required to include all of the facts that may be necessary to establish that an act or omission constituted a breach of duty. (For example, it is not necessary to plead that there was a reasonably practicable precaution or alternative course of conduct that could have avoided or reduced the loss or damage — even if evidence to that effect would be required at the trial Collendina Pty Ltd v Murray Darling Basin Commission [2006] NSWSC 776; BC200606106 at [22] .)

Damage must be pleaded as it is an essential element of the cause of action in negligence (and in other torts): Donoghue v Stevenson [1932] AC 562 at 618 . If damages for bodily injury are claimed, the defendant is entitled to particulars of the nature and extent of the plaintiff's bodily injury and any consequential economic loss. Particulars of the latter kind may include the nature of the plaintiff's occupation, pre-injury income and period of consequential disability: Lawson v Ryan (1939) 56 WN (NSW) 68. In a claim for economic loss for negligent misstatement, it is necessary to allege (and therefore prove) that the defendant knew or ought to reasonably have known that the information or advice in the statement would be communicated to the plaintiff, either individually or as a member of an identified class and that this would be for a purpose very likely to lead the plaintiff to enter into the particular kind of transaction: Esanda Finance Corp Ltd v Peat Marwick Hungerfords (1997) 188 CLR 241 at 252, 256–7, 263, 275; 142 ALR 750 at 757, 761, 765, 776; [1997] HCA 8; BC9700700 .

A defendant who seeks to make out an affirmative defence may be required to provide particulars. For example, a defendant who pleads inevitable accident may be ordered to give further particulars of that defence: Cook v Nash [1958] Qd R 1. However, since the defence of inevitable accident is no more than a denial of negligence and does not shift the legal burden of proof (Jockel v Jockel [1963] SR (NSW) 230 ; Dowsing v Goodwin (NSWCA, No 40423/95 and 40424/95, 10 November 1997, unreported) ; K and S Freighters Pty Ltd v Nelmeer Hoteliers Pty Ltd (2001) 33 MVR 467; [2001] NSWCA 151; BC200103009 ), this will be rare.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 15.6] r 15.6 Claims for out of pocket expenses (cf SCR Part 16, rule 5; DCR Part 9, rule 23; LCR Part 8, rule 5)

leg:heading.title: Claims for out of pocket expenses (cf SCR Part 16, rule 5; DCR Part 9, rule 23; LCR Part 8, rule 5)

p.text: A party pleading who claims damages that include money that he or she has paid or is liable to pay must give particulars of that money.

The particulars of out of pocket expenses should include full details of all amounts incurred in the past, or likely to be incurred in the future, in respect of medical, hospital and rehabilitative treatment, along with medication expenses. The inclusion under this rule of particulars of moneys paid does not convert an action for money had and received into one for damages: Plytarias v Andrews [1974] 2 NSWLR 382 .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 15.7] r 15.7 Claims for exemplary damages (cf SCR Part 16, rule 5A)

leg:heading.title: Claims for exemplary damages (cf SCR Part 16, rule 5A)

p.text: The particulars to be given by a pleading that claims exemplary damages must state the facts and circumstances on which the party pleading relies to establish that claim.

Exemplary damages will only be awarded in a limited class of cases in tort and never in contract: Australian Consolidated Press Ltd v Uren [1969] 1 AC 590; (1969) 117 CLR 221; BC6600050 ; Uren v John Fairfax & Sons Pty Ltd (1966) 117 CLR 118; [1967] ALR 25 ; Whitfield v De Lauret & Co Ltd (1920) 29 CLR 71; 27 ALR 249 ; XL Petroleum (NSW) Pty Ltd v Caltex Oil (Aust) Pty Ltd (1985) 155 CLR 448; 57 ALR 639 ; Rookes v Barnard [1964] AC 1129; [1964] 1 All ER 367 . As to general particulars with respect to damages, see [15.1.40] and [15.10.15] .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 15.8] r 15.8 Claims for aggravated damages (cf SCR Part 16, rule 5B)

leg:heading.title: Claims for aggravated damages (cf SCR Part 16, rule 5B)

p.text: The particulars to be given by a pleading that claims aggravated compensatory damages must state the facts and circumstances on which the party pleading relies to establish that claim.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 15.9] r 15.9 Manner of giving particulars (cf SCR Part 16, rule 6; DCR Part 9, rule 25; LCR Part 8, rule 6)

leg:heading.title: Manner of giving particulars (cf SCR Part 16, rule 6; DCR Part 9, rule 25; LCR Part 8, rule 6)

p.text: The particulars to be given by a pleading must be set out in the pleading or, if that is inconvenient, must be set out in a separate document referred to in the pleading and filed with the pleading.

The manner in which particulars must be given is set out in r 15.9. Consistent with that rule, it is insufficient merely to advise the opponent that they can inform themselves by perusing documents: Australian Hardwoods Pty Ltd v Cmr for Railways [1961] NSWR 25 ; see also English, Scottish & Australian Bank v Dwyer [1969] 1 NSWR 459 and Engarch Pty Ltd v Ocean Shores Pty Ltd [1970] 3 NSWR 204 . It is also insufficient to say that a party will rely on such facts as are in the knowledge of the other party and which will appear in the evidence at the hearing of the action: Atkinson v Stewart & Partners [1954] NI 146 at 158; Zanardo v Ford Motor Co of Australia Ltd [1964] VR 769 . A plaintiff who can establish the likelihood of a particular type of publication may be entitled to obtain discovery of the details of the publication in order to able to provide the required particulars: Kaiser v George Laurens (NSW) Pty Ltd [1982] 1 NSWLR 294 (publication by credit agency); Ahmed v John Fairfax Publications Pty Ltd [2006] NSWSC 11; BC200600202 (international publication by newspaper).

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 15.10] r 15.10 Order for particulars (cf SCR Part 16, rule 7; DCR Part 9, rule 26; LCR Part 8, rule 8)

leg:heading.title: Order for particulars (cf SCR Part 16, rule 7; DCR Part 9, rule 26; LCR Part 8, rule 8)

p.text: The court may order a party to file:
particulars of any claim, defence or other matter stated in the party’s pleading or in any affidavit relevant to the proceedings, or
a statement of the nature of the case on which the party relies, or
if the party claims damages, particulars relating to general or other damages.
Without limiting subrule (1), if a pleading alleges that a person had knowledge or notice of some fact, matter or thing, the court may order that party to file:
if the pleading alleges knowledge, particulars of the facts on which that party relies, and
if the pleading alleges notice, particulars of the notice.

If particulars are not given in accordance with the rules in the pleading or in a document accompanying the pleading and if a party refuses after being asked by letter to furnish further and better particulars, an application may be made to the court. The court has a wide discretion to order further particulars wherever the proper administration of justice requires (Bailey v FCT (1977) 136 CLR 214 at 227–8; 13 ALR 41 ) and particulars may be ordered even if they are not strictly necessary to limit the extent of the evidence given at the trial or to prevent surprise at the trial and are merely supplemental to the pleadings: Milbank v Milbank [1900] 1 Ch 376 at 385 . If the party from whom particulars are sought genuinely objects that it cannot provide the particulars, or can only do so after laborious research or exhaustive enquiry, the proper order is that the best particulars be supplied which the party can give at that time with liberty to provide further particulars after discovery and inspection: Marshall v Inter Oceanic Steam Yachting Co (1885) 1 TLR 394 ; Race Relations Board v Ealing London Borough Council (No 2) [1978] 1 All ER 497; [1978] 1 WLR 112 . Whether the court will refuse to make an order for particulars until after discovery involves a balancing of interests of the parties: Lyons v Kern Constructions (Townsville) Pty Ltd (1983) 47 ALR 114; 70 FLR 135 at 148–151 .

The usual order is that the relevant particulars (identifying them, often by reference to the letter requesting them) be furnished within a certain time, together with an appropriate order for costs. While the court may order that the action be dismissed, or that the defence be struck out and the plaintiff be at liberty to enter judgment, if the particulars are not supplied by a certain date, such orders are nowadays rarely made and, if at all, generally only on a subsequent motion when the first order has not been obeyed. If made, the appropriate form of order is that the proceedings be dismissed, or that the plaintiff be at liberty to enter judgment, unless within a specified time the order for particulars is complied with: Davey v Bentick [1893] 1 QB 185 ; Nixon v W Phelan & Son Pty Ltd [1959] VR 83 ; Douglas v John Fairfax & Sons Ltd [1983] 3 NSWLR 126 (no power to make a self-executing order precluding a party from leading evidence on a pleaded issue). Even where there is default in compliance with a direction contained in such an order (and as a consequence the order for dismissal of proceedings takes effect), the court retains a discretionary power to extend time for compliance pursuant to r 1.12. In exercising its powers to extend time there is a preference, if the balance of discretionary considerations otherwise permits, to allow proceedings to be heard on their merits: Southern Cross Exploration NL v Fire & All Risks Insurance Co Ltd (1986) 7 NSWLR 319 ; Morgan v 45 Flers Avenue Pty Ltd (1987) 11 NSWLR 573 at 578, 580, 581 ; Paino v Hofbauer (1988) 13 NSWLR 193 at 196–7, 200 ; FAI General Insurance Co Ltd v Southern Cross Exploration NL (1988) 165 CLR 268; 77 ALR 411; BC8802594 ; see also r 36.16.

There is no obligation to give particulars of a claim for general damages: Singleton v John Fairfax & Sons Ltd (No 2) [1983] 2 NSWLR 728 at 730 . This rule, however, gives the court power to make an order to provide such particulars in an appropriate case.

The grant of an order for particulars is discretionary. A relevant matter in the exercise of the discretion is that the person seeking the particulars already knows, or ought to know, the relevant details, and it would, as a consequence, be oppressive or unreasonable to make an order. However, because a person is entitled to know the allegations being made against them, and because the allegations may differ both from the person's “knowledge” and from the “true” position, knowledge of itself will not be sufficient to defeat an application for an order that particulars be provided: Palmos v Georgeson [1961] Qd R 186 at 193 ; Turner v Dalgety & Co Pty Ltd (1952) 69 WN (NSW) 228 at 229 ; Lawson v Perpetual Trustee Co Ltd (1959) 76 WN (NSW) 367 ; Philliponi v Leithead (1958) 59 SR (NSW) 352 at 359; 76 WN (NSW) 150; Emmerton v University of Sydney [1970] 2 NSWR 633 at 635 ; Bailey v FCT (1977) 136 CLR 214 at 219, 220, 221; 13 ALR 41 .

Consistent with the general principles discussed at [15.1.10] , an application for an order for particulars is concerned with the adequacy of the particulars supplied to make the other party aware of the case it is called upon to meet. Particulars are not concerned with the adequacy of the information to actually establish the case sought to be made out: Sims v Wran [1984] 1 NSWLR 317 at 329 .

In New South Wales, despite the practice elsewhere, it has been customary to seek particulars of a pleading before replying to it. Despite older cases, particulars are even ordered in England in modern times where the lack of them could prejudice or embarrass the party in its pleading in reply: Selangor United Rubber Estates Ltd v Cradock [1965] Ch 896 . Although an application for an order that particulars be provided may be made at any time, it should be made promptly and may, in the court’s discretion, be refused if there has been undue delay: Murnin v United Assurance Co (1867) 6 SCR (NSW) (L) 262; Astrovlanis Compania Naviera SA v Linard [1972] 2 QB 611 .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 15.11] r 15.11 Particulars concerning claims under Property (Relationships) Act 1984

leg:heading.title: Particulars concerning claims under Property (Relationships) Act 1984

p.text: The particulars to be given by a pleading with respect to a claim for relief under section 20(1) of the Property (Relationships) Act 1984 must include:
particulars of any payment on which the plaintiff relies as to any contribution referred to in that subsection, and
particulars of any document on which the plaintiff relies as evidence that any such payment has been made.
